intro: Savia danguyana, commonly known as the African spurge, is a flowering plant native to parts of Africa. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its succulent, fleshy stems and leaves. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically clustered in cyathia, which are specialized inflorescences. It is often found in arid or semi-arid environments, thriving in well-drained soils. The plant contains toxic compounds, making it potentially harmful to livestock and humans if ingested.
